question.title: Kafka Streams State store behaving differently if stream is converted beforehand
question.body:
I am expiriencing a very weird behaviour in my kafka streams application. Setup is the following:

  • I create the state store "user-store" manually and connect it to a processor "filter-role-processor"
  • I use the DSL to process the incoming Stream with the connected processor
  • Inside the processor, I try to get() values out of the above mentioned state store

This works fine. I get what I try to get from the store.

Now my setup should be extended: The "filter-role-processor" should be applied later in the topology. Between that I convert the incoming stream into a table, process it, and convert it back into a stream using DSL.
BUT: Now the get() calls to the state store work no longer! I receive null values for the exact same keys that worked just fine before I double-converted the input stream. Also, debugging inside the processor shows the exact same records arriving both ways, just the state store delivers a different result.

To me this is weird - the keys used for querying the store are identical, why am I receiving different results? Is there anything I can check/change?

This works as expected:

public KStream<String, Roles> filteredRolesKStream() {
    return inputKStream
                .process(FilterRoleProcessor::new, Named.as("filter-role-processor"));
}

This does not:

public KStream<String, Roles> filteredRolesKStream() {
    return inputKStream
            .toTable(Materialized.<String, Roles, KeyValueStore<Bytes, byte[]>>as(
                            "test-table")
                    .withKeySerde(Serdes.String())
                    .withValueSerde(new JsonSerde<>(Roles.class).noTypeInfo())
            )
            .toStream()
            .process(FilterRoleProcessor::new, Named.as("filter-role-processor"));
}

The filter-role-processor and user-store are connected like this:

builder.addStateStore(inMemoryRoleStore)
.build()
.connectProcessorAndStateStores("filter-role-processor", "user-store")

The filter-role-processor is coded like that:

public void process(Record<String, Roles> userRoleRecord) {
    ReadOnlyKeyValueStore<String, String> relevantUsers = ctx.getStateStore("user-store");
    
    // Key of the userRoleRecord is the userId which is also the key of entries in the user-store. The value in the store is a string representing if the user is active or not.
    String storeValue = relevantUsers.get(userRoleRecord.key());
    if (storeValue != null && storeValue.equals("true")) ctx.forward(userRoleRecord);
    else log.info("User {} is not active, dropping event", userRoleRecord.key());
}

question_comments.body: I don't know how inputStream is created, but yes, if there was an upstream key-changing operation, a repartition topic might be created: however, the repartition topic would, be default, get the same number of partitions as the upstream input topic. -- So I am not sure right now, where a difference in number of partitions would come from. If it's really a problem with number of partitions, you can use repartition() operator (before calling toTable()) and set the desired number of partitions via Repartition parameter.

Of course @MatthiasJ.Sax, you are right, this was not very clear.  I added more code of the regarding classes, but I think I know what is the problem. The processor filling the statestore is consuming a topic with a single partition. The FilterRoleProcessor is receiving a 12-partition stream.   If a role arrives from partition 0, it actually finds the regarding value in the store. I think, by transforming it into a table and back into a stream I am doing a repartioning action.  How can I best solve this store-sharding problem?
Not sure if I understand the setup end-to-end. There is no code which shows how you connect the state store, or what FilterRoleProcessor does. Can you share more details?
@FactoreT thanks, learned something new today... i wrongly assumed it was just by the name :)
@JorgeCampos This post is regarding Kafka Streams and not Java InputStreams

Thank you for your comments, but I think they are both not related to the problem.  @AndreiLisa I have a value present for every key I request from the state store, but the answer is null just sometimes (if I do the conversion mentioned above).
An inputstream in java is a read once. You likely need to make a copy of your inputstream to be able to read it again.
null values in the stream are interpreted as delete events in the KTable â€” these create key with null value.
